Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2007 04:42PM gracejon wrote: I do not know if wrapping is the same as using a Jovipak but it does take a while after getting measured to receive one.  Wrapping I assume is more effective for an increase in acute or new swelling.  I was wrapped and kept the same wrapping on for days.  I think I remember using big painters gloves to keep things clean when doing tasks.  I had more swelling when I had expanders in and once they were out swelling became easier to control.  Have you learned to do manual lymph drainage yet?  It does help.
Posts.Title: Cannot Wrap - Will Jovipak do the same as wrapping CharlotteG sccruiser

Posts.Content: gracejon wrote: My friend was diagnosed with DCIS.  Went to a big cancer center for oncologist and treatment.  Had a lumpectomy elsewhere.  Pathology at first place, as I understand it ,read slides as 1 mm of DCIS'  Medical oncologist read the written report and opinion was surgery done with lumpectomy and now radiation.  Breast cancer surgeon a BC center after treatment said no need to follow up since that doc did not do the surgery.  In a effort to find someone for follow up care had a second opinion with breast specialist that involved center's pathology reading the slides and saying there was NO CANCER IN THE FIRST PLACE!  Her quandry now is what to do for follow up.  Oncologist took her off tamoxifen and by her report said that drug was too strong to give for no cancer.  She remains at high risk cause of atypical cells and LCIS and I also believe because she had radiation.  Doesn't radiation increase your chance of cancer by the changes it does on a cellular level?  Clearly in my mind she needs follow up by a breast center.  I think I would also send my slides for another opinion to Sloan or Anderson and expect to give her my opinion on that one.  She is torn about who to see and what to do so I thought before I gave her my opinion in total, I would ask you all.  Please help!  BTW I think you guys are definitely smarter than me! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Misdiagnosed friend what would you do? gracejon otter

Posts.Content: gracejon wrote: Had a visit from occupational guys today. I am very happy to report they seem interested in helping but I was at a loss to give info on how often LE develops. I do know that it increases with radiation and surgery and ?number of nodes removed but somewhere I thought I saw 2/3's of people who had surgery and radiation will develop LE. Does anyone have the current stats. I did emphasize that any suggestions that work could be published since very little info is out there. I do think the hand compression issue is hopeless because of handwashing requirements. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 04:27PM - edited Sep 1, 2008 04:28PM by gracejon Annie, my drain never went down to allowable amount until I stopped trying to be superwoman; Microwave meals, can the cleaning and no exercise for three to five days; It definitely will make a difference; I had one of those buggers in for almost 6 weeks until I finally calmed down.
Posts.Title: REWARD! Box of CHOCOLATES! HeatherBLocklear AnneW

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 02:30PM gracejon wrote: Anne, I think you got it completely right.  She was diagnosed and treated.  After all was said and done in an attempt to get breast care follow up, a new doctor requested path slides be sent to her center's pathology department and were read as NO CANCER and atypia with LCIS.  I guess the crux of the matter is a community hospital read it as cancer, the breast center pathologist read it as no cancer but after the fact as she was treated for the DCIS by standard of care.  BTW her oncologist and radiation was done by the breast center but they did not ask for the slides to review prior to or during treatment.  They went on the written report by the community pathologist.  The center pathologist specialize and only read breast pathology slides where I believe the community pathologist reads all slides.  I did think that some girls here are taking hormonal therapy for LCIS.  I do not remember if she ever told me how aggressive her DCIS was but I do remember her reporting her one doctor said this was almost not a cancer.  I can not imagine how violiated I would feel if this happend to me.
Posts.Title: Misdiagnosed friend what would you do? gracejon otter

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2007 01:53PM gracejon wrote: after revision surgery I had a lt of bleeding from the left side.  Staff ace bandaged my chest very tightly to stop the bleeding.  Compression was added for a month around my chest without hurting pre existing lymphedema.  The compression did a number I think on my ultimate outcome of nipple reconstruction but did not affect lymphedema issues.
Posts.Title: Help PS just bound me?????? sharebear gracejon

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 12:47PM gracejon wrote: I loved to read Kimmy's post.  So sad.  Peace to her and her family.
Posts.Title: Kimmytoo Sachi justjudie

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2008 06:32AM - edited Aug 9, 2008 06:34AM by gracejon I think affairs are horrible.  Although one can never condon them, my personal take is that I have been sliced and diced,drugged, burnt and have a libido of an amoeba.  I am on hormones to improve this but am about one half an iota better.  Hormones are taken to improve the quality of my days but not exactly given without reservations.  I love my husband.  If given the circumstances, I could not meet all his needs, I would not find it a reason to throw him under the rug.  Of course I'd be hurt but I am sure if he made that decision he would be hurting also.  I like LuAnn would wonder about the woman who chose to be involved.  I am very lucky to have a husband that understands and I do try to meet his needs even though I don't feel like it.  I expect how awful some of these treatments are and how diabilitating  you feel, that is hard to pick and choose what part of your family gets your attention and what gets left out.  As for me if I need to pick and choose where my energy goes, my child wins every time.  If I need to choose between my employment and financially helping to support my family and activities, work wins over hubby.  The best solution is balance and for the most part it works.  I do know along the journey there have been stretches it didn't.  Again thank God my husband is understanding.
Posts.Title: Can you believe John Edwards? waterlily Daffodil

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 01:04PM - edited Aug 17, 2008 01:05PM by gracejon I do wear a watch and wedding bands on my left affected hand.  I have been very lucky as my swelling in my hand has been thumb and index, middle fingers only along with that portion of my hand.  My glove gets worn over my bands although I am a nurse and for the most part of the day my hand remains ungloved cause of washing issues.  I found that I could not wear a watch with a band that does not expand and have taken to wear bracelet types that are not completely enclosed so expansion can occur if swelling increases.  During much of the year my swelling is pretty stable and all is well.  During the heat humidity of the summer it is mostly a guess on how swollen things will become.  Since my thumb is usually first to be noticable, when this swells I know to start monitoring things more closely.  I also can move rings and things to my right unaffected hand if need be and certainly at times do.
Posts.Title: Do you wear a watch or rings? porchchair inspiewriter

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 07:48PM gracejon wrote: I also want to add I always take my rings off at bedtime.

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2008 04:57PM gracejon wrote: Everyone has brought up great points.  Regardless of what one chooses I think expectation is the same, a  successful outcome.  Of course none of it is a guarantee and should one has recurrence or metastasis, could of, should of thoughts will be entertained.  As for reconstruction, I would expect it and should expect it to be successful and reality is sometimes none of this works out as we wish or expect.  I too agree there is no right or wrong decisions and only pretty equal choices.  We can all go back to the early days when doctors told you what to do and gave you no choices.  At least now we do understand we have choices.  These decisions are tough and really up to the individual.  No one should beat themselves up with the choices they make because again they are equal.
Posts.Title: Have I made the wrong decision?? Brenny FrannyK

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2008 06:46PM gracejon wrote: Bessie, the truth be told, I had an awful time getting to successful reconstruction.  I was in an HMO that had really no one that wanted to do breast reconstruction and I ended up with a guy that was doing it because he was low man on the totem pole and to keep his position and please his boss, he was elected to take on this task.  I lost my first attempt and struggled with my HMO to get sent out of the system.  I am very pleased with my final outcome and yes they are esthetically more pleasing than the originals except they really are for the most part pretty numb.  My HMO still has the same guy doing all of the reconstruction and since he's had 4years of practice, I suspect he's better at it than in my day.  I certainly added to his practice in trying to get better at it.  Needless to say I have become a big advocate of plastic surgeons subspecializing in breast reconstruction with further training and certification in breast reconstruction.  This surgeon and his partner juryrigged microsurgery and flap creation to fit breast reconstruction instead of training in this specifically.  Same way with implants and LD flaps.  See one, read about one and do one in my mind is not in tune with the patient's best interest.  I guess I think in many of the aspects of this BC journey I was fed a bill of goods.  Easy to do when one is afraid and has no where to turn in a short period of time. I would not have changed my mind about what was best for me.  Again I think a choice is exactly what we needs and this is clearly not one option fits everyone.  It is a hard decision particularly because you do feel rushed to get the cancer out and treatment started.  My successful reconstruction was relatively easy.  Had I not been so scared and really had looked into the qualification of my original PS my first attempt may have been successful also.   My best lesson learned is that I certainly have become a more saavy and assertive medical consumer which for me has been very helpful.
Posts.Title: Have I made the wrong decision?? Brenny FrannyK

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 06:34AM gracejon wrote: It helps to declare "I don't know how to help but please share what you are thinking with me" I love you and will do what you think"  Another thing is do without asking.  Run the vacuum, do the dishes, go to the appointments if she would like you there. Let her do the talking about results if she wishes.  Apologize quickly if you do something out of turn. Do keep communicating and don't feel that anything is a personal attack on you.  A girl sometimes feels pretty grumpy during this stuff.  Particularly in the very beginning when so much of what you are going to do and what is recoemmended is still unknown.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2008 08:53AM gracejon wrote: My best friend had a breast reduction and the pathologist found atypia.  Her surgeon sent her to an oncologist to discuss her risk of breast cancer and her treatment options.  She chose to use tamoxifen through the oncologist to decrease her risk of breast cancer.  I do think an oncology visit would be very helpful to you should this new episode be nothing to worry about.  It would seem to be the logical decision in determining your future risks and possibly give you a path to decrease them if the oncologist thinks you are at risk.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2006 11:09AM gracejon wrote: Congratulations Pat. Although I am having very little problems currently and have been able to forego sleeves and things without exacerbation and only my tolerable baseline swelling, I feel very uncomfortable wearing compression garments to work. I do believe my coworkers feel intimidated by my wearing them hence one of the reasons I stopped (but to clarify, I have not had an increase in symptoms either). As Pat has said in the past, it is impossible to use a compression glove while working in a clinical setting. Without the glove and only sleeve, my hand looks like a rubber glove someone tried to blow up halfway. I have been very fortunate that I have not had any sequela from foregoing the standard compression. I do wear it for hiking, flying and more strenuous exercise.
Posts.Title: What do you want nurses to know about lymphedema? NPat Suzybelle

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2008 09:02AM gracejon wrote: I am a pediatric nurse in a ambulatory setting.  We see well kids for routine care but the majority of our practice is sick kids with things like MRSA, strep and horrible coughs and colds.  Worked through all of it.  I was very cautious to use good infection control but did not do anything special than my normal routine with handwashing etc.  I do think my families did help out my coralling their sick kids in their laps more than usual but they respected the ole bald lady me with hats on her head cause I could not tolerate wearing that itchy wig for 10 hours a day.  My families still ask me if I am walking for Making Strides or Komen if they can contribute.  I certainly made a difference with routine check ups with many moms. I did just fine and did not miss any extra work other than chemo days.  I was assigned a normal schedule which included evenings and Saturdays.
Posts.Title: working with children ladyjane54 Onehalf

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2008 05:50PM gracejon wrote: Call your doctor, please!  Many things caused bone pain.  After Neulasta I had bone pain.  With an AI I had bone pain.  The biphosphonates, I had bone pain but I never tried to figure it out myself and it did involve getting a couple of bone scans to make sure nothing else was going on.  I think guessing is a really bad idea.  Please take care of yourself and ring your doctor.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 07:12PM gracejon wrote: Deb as a nurse that has accessed ports for kids with and without chemo, our practice knows who is a difficult stick after a few times.  The ones that have not had any difficulty should and do get accessed by everyone.  On the other hand we have a few patients that have individual nurses that tend to be more successful than others.  Susie can always do Hannah, Mary always seems to successful with Sophie, etc.  If you never have had a problem previously I don't think you over reacted.  Particularly if you could notice she was in the wrong spot from the get go.  I probably at that point would have screamed stop and get me someone else to do this!

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 09:58AM gracejon wrote: I have not had any arguments from nursing, radiology techs or phlebotomy techs.  My issues have come from doctors.  Gynecological oncologist said not using that arm for B/Ps or blood draws was overkill.  Anesthesia doctor used it for BPs during surgery and said to me when I protested that they would put it on the other arm after I fell asleep.  I don't personally believe that actually happened and did have a bit of an exacerbation for about a month after that surgery..  When the marketing people at the hopspital called to get my opinion on my care.  I did say that I believe this incident should be written up as a violation and error.  It has been my experience that if a doctor did it, it is not an error but wrote off as "off label" or procedural difference okayed by doctor.  I do tend to be very tough on doctors and want everyone to know I do have some great doctors taking care of me but also have some not so great.  I do thik a patient definitely needs to advocate for themselves

Posts.Title: Study: New way to spot breast cancer shows prom gracejon lilsunshine

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2008 04:17PM gracejon wrote: The experimental method -- molecular breast imaging, or MBI -- would not replace mammograms for women at average risk of the disease. But it might become an additional tool for higher risk women with a lot of dense tissue that makes tumors hard to spot on mammograms, and it could be done at less cost than an MRI, or magnetic resonance imaging. About one-fourth of women 40 and older have dense breasts.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 06:16PM - edited Sep 4, 2008 06:18PM by gracejon http://www.psa-rising.com/med/chemo/fatigue.htm Some patients report benefit from stimulant drugs such as Ritalin (methylphenidate) or Provigil (modafinil). Provigil was not designed for cancer patients, it is used mainly to treat people with narcolepsy. It has some troublesome side effects. In a clinical trial, 74 of the 934 patients (8%) who received PROVIGIL dropped out compared to 3% of patients that received placebo. The most frequent reasons for stopping Provigil were headache, nausea, anxiety, dizziness, insomnia, chest pain and nervousness.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2007 05:35PM gracejon wrote: I say that my arm swells and my sleeve is my support hose for my arm. My best experience was riding in the elevator at the hospital where I work, a general surgery resident looked at my wrapped arm (actively wrapped with the foam, short stretch bandages and guaze to try to get some control) and said that must have been one hell of a break. To him I said "No, lymphedema from one of your staff doing surgery" I do hold a bit of a grudge since I already had lymphedema in my legs prior to breast surgery and the doctor totally ignored my concern. I had negative SNB and this department still always does an axillary dissection. I can't lose sleep over what coulda, shoulda been done but I still get a bit out of joint thinking about it. I do have very good control currently so I should be very grateful.
Posts.Title: How to explain to children? MarieL NPat

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2007 03:44PM gracejon wrote: I so totally agree with Binney about whatever works for you.  I do think it rather odd that certain areas seem to accumulate swelling more than others.  I have had a lot of luck with day copression and night sleeve but day compression make my hand worse mostly cause to wash hands I don and remove glove frequently. My only problem area that seems most difficult is my thumb and I wrap this with waterproof nexus sport tape or sometimes Coban under glove/night sleeve.  I feel very fortunate that for most I have great control.  It was quite an experiment trying to find what works and even with great control, it still remains a "work in progress"  Every now and again I hear or see something in my wanderings to try to improve things.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 11:11PM - edited Aug 30, 2008 11:12PM by gracejon First did he doctor culture the fluid prior to putting you on antibiotics cause once you have that break infection is more likely?  If the antibiotic is not the right one, it is useless to treat any infection brewing. Generally once you start on any antibiotic it become more difficult to identify correctly any bacteria that may be present.  As a preventive antibiotic there are definitely certain types that are used.  Secondly if a drain isn't place any more accumulated fluid will drain at the path of least resistance and come out the breach already created by the bursting.  Therefore the most likely scenario is placing a drain and leaving it in until the drainage is minimal. I think I understand by what I have read that breast surgery tends to develop draining  by the nature of the area so this is why drains are frequently used.  I am clearly not any type expert and only became interested because of my own experience with bursting seroma.  So sorry you had this happen and will hope that your current treatment works even though it ,in my opinion only , doesn't follow standard therapies.  Again I hope this approach works for you even though I think it may be a bit unusual.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 08:25PM gracejon wrote: Laura, I do think answering the phone when you were ready gave you a bit of control.  I felt like I lost my control over me in the early going.  Statistics are mostly old and don't give up the up tp date information.  I was diagnosed 4 years ago and even in that period of time so much has changed.  Accurate staging is pivotal and even then understanding statistics out there are at least 2 years old.  Plus numbers are all over the line depending on what book you pick up.  The girls here posting are making the current statistics and as lon as we are posting we are not adding to percentages.  Educate yourself and don't listen to well meaning friends that give you all those horror stories.  Once you get plans in place, you can feel a lot better.  Giving up clients may be a bit premature.  Most of us either worked full time or only took a couple of days off here and there.  Although I felt bad at times, I never missed an assigned shift as a nurse working with kids in a hospital.  Handwashing, healthy foods and rest kept me well and not overly focused on surgery, chemo and all the other stuff.  It sounds like you have a great family and that is very important.  I totally expected to feel bad and NEVER felt as bad as I had imagined.
Posts.Title: Didn't have it in me Estepp CathyaMom

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2007 12:23PM gracejon wrote: All life's tragedies!  My relationship with my church has surely changed.  I asked for help with transportation and got no response.  My relationship with God has changed over the years but is strong.  I watched my dad stab my mom.  I was placed in a family that depending on their need was the girl that came to live with them or another daughter.  My husband and I dealt with infertility and was fortunate to adopt a newborn that ultimately had disabilities (unknown at the time).  I look at all these things as shaping my life, truly making me a good person.  My God is one of the hands I hold but He didn't cause this nor does He want me to suffer.  He supports me in my journey.  On the other hand the earth people in church may have been helpful and chose no response.  I did volunteer as much as I could during my good times and am disappointed that when I needed a bit no one was able.  I no longer attend.  I do feel guilty that it puts me in the same category and hopefully someday will be able to get past it.  Just hope God forgives me. I am sure He understands.

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2008 10:19AM - edited Aug 11, 2008 10:29AM by gracejon I love the name of your book!  "The Courage Muscle: a Chicken's Guide to Living with Breast Cancer"  The medical term for this burn phenomenen is PPE  Palmar, Plantar Erythrodysesthesia.  I had this problem with A/C alone and since it was Christmas Eve my cancer center told me that it never happens with my drug combo and talk to your PCP.  Of course my PCP did diagnose it and I told him it couldn't be cause the experts said impossible.  I also emailed one of BC..org posters doctor since she got it on the same combo.  He said of course it can and does.  Took the email to my oncologist.  He then agreed it could and to prevent recurrence I was talking a B vitamin think it was B6.  For the short term he had put all his patient's on B vitamin and his nurse said they changed practice cause of me.  He then quit to go into research so I expect it is no longer anyone's practice.  Anyway I guess my point is this side effects can be minimized by B vitamins and happens with different chemo drugs for other reasons. Glad to hear something that offers relief and would try  this in a heartbeat. Thank you MDS.

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 11:31AM gracejon wrote: I have been hypothyroid for years and had a ultrasound when I was diagnosed for BC.  Radiologist read a lot into ultrasound and said I had to see endo right away.  Endo doc said ultrasound is not a good way to image thyroid and redid it in his office.  Endo sound me right then and there how solid and flouid filled lesions could be produced by small twist of wand.  I recently had ultrasound repeated and over a couple years thyroid is shrinking to nothing and those solid and fluid filled lesions are still present.  Endo would do biopsy if he thought it was necessary but he also feels more comfortable with his own ultrasounds then one done in radiology.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2007 06:08PM gracejon wrote: After bilateral mastectomy, I was discovered to have more calcifications.  Someone said that this is common after these procedures.  Perhaps for reassurance you might ask if calcifications in the lumpectomy area occur what chances and what would be the diagnostic workup of further things.  I suspect if I had known this was a possibility, I would not have gotten so un nerved by the call back for more views.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2007 08:08AM gracejon wrote: I am sorry to hear about your current scare. It totally sucks! I do want to get you prepared for thyroid biopsy results that come back as inconclusive. Those kind of results with thyroid biopsies happen pretty frequently and further draw out a the stress levels. Thinking of you and praying all will be fine. Since you mentioned lymphedema of the face. I do wonder if lymphedema of my face would fill out my wrinkles and give me a more youthful appearance. Certainly if they use those wrinkle fillers, couldn't lymphedema do the same job. (only joking) I do know that my hand lymphedema has made that hand's wrinkles. disappear. Who knows it might catch on?

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2007 09:21PM gracejon wrote: Sherry 7, I only have one LE certified therapist in network.  The Vodder trained therapist does upper post breast cancer and there is another that does only lower limb therapy.  The fact is although no one commiserates with the pain issue, it isn't disabiling or I would make a bigger fuss.  I do slack off at times with massage and even sometimes wearing of the sleeve.  I do think I have a handle on what conditions exist that I can pre emptively be a bit more aggressive in my therapy like hot humid weather.  I did see therapist not so long ago and she has commented on how much better swelling is when we first started.  I do think the health care system that dictates my providers is not very attuned to lymphedema and is a bit lackadaisical regarding avoiding limbs etc.  I have seen a peripheral vascular doc specializing in lymphedema and she has been very helpful but that does not change the rest of the group to pay heed to precautions.  I do think everyone is their own best advocate but sometimes to be believable when you need it, you must keep quiet about some not so bothersome stuff.  Believe me, I can cause quite a stir if needed and have done so in the past.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 08:42AM gracejon wrote: I've pretty much noticed I can do anything as long as I don't do too much of it.  Any over and over repetitive behavior has resulted in increase in swelling but if I take it easy and stop prior to feeling heavy or fatigue in general I am okay.  Stopping earlier in times of heat and humidity has also been prudent for me.  Living with lymphedema for a while you learn your individual limitations and try to stay within them.  Of course at times a curve ball is thrown and one needs to reevaluate what works.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 05:12PM gracejon wrote: Gabi, you do have a lot of homework to do!  I have always thought the previvors who actively choose how much to do to decrease risks are far more brave than I.  It was pretty much a no brainer for me once I got cancer.  I had it all done breasts, ovaries.  I do feel more comfortable with myself thinking that I did all I could do.  BUT... not everyone can do that and certainly I am not sure what I would do if I did not have active cancer.  I do know when I was looking for information of breast reconstruction and particularly the DIEP technique, I found that DIEP originated in Japan.  I am glad you found this site and am wishing you well.
